title: Bank acquisitions during the 2008 financial crisis
prompt:
What banks for famously bought by other banks in the 2008 financial crisis
What did Jp Morgan pay ?
What role did the fed play in these acquisitions ?
Why did jpmorgan need the feds help in the acquisitions?
Were any of the acquisitions during the financial crisis not facilitated by the Fed?
Why would the FDIC agree to absorb any losses of the deal?

How much funding can the treasury provide and where does the fed come into play in this?
Why did the fed intervene in financial crisis then if the FDIC had enough money to cover losses.
Ok so the FDIC solves issues where the bank has already failed and the fed helps avoid those failures before they happen
If banks require loans from the fed and then depositors withdraw a lot of money, they will need to sell assets to repay the loans and depositors. What happens to the market for the assets the banks have to sell?
Assume the bank has to sell treasuries, if a lot of other banks have to sell the same bond assets, what happens to that market?
If banks were facing potential failure and had to sell their bonds, the yields increase, but the fed could reduce interest rates. How would that effect the market? Seems like unless the fed is buying the bonds that lower rates wouldn’t matter
Ya it wouldn’t make sense for the market to buy the more expensive bonds with the lower rates when there are cheaper bonds on the market being mass sold by banks in this scenario
If the fed was actually in the process of hiking interest rates due to inflation concerns, while at the same time banks were mass selling bonds, what should the fed do? Yields would be increasing in the market and they don’t want liquidity to dry up but they also don’t want inflation to increase more by adding liquidity to the system. Sorry I meant to say 500 word. Please provide a summary of this thread in 500 words which explains in an article format. It should conclude with the options for the fed in this situation of a banking system collapse while they are trying to reduce inflation with higher interest rates
Awesome summary, can you make it a little more concise?
What if FDIC can’t find a buyer for the failed bank. Does it just start liquidating the assets individually and try to repay depositors over time?
Why is the FDIC obligated to protect depositors of the bank with deposits greater than the guaranteed 250k per person amount?
What incentive does a large bank have in buying a failed bank from FDIC? If the assets are sound, would the FDIC just sell the assets so it can make a profit or does it prefer not to do the work and have another bank take on the obligation
Would anyone buy the failed bank if it was clear that the liabilities of the failed bank offset their assets?
Could the fdic back any potential losses for the acquirer?
In the 2008 financial crisis which banks failed and weren’t acquired ? Why were they not acquired compared to the banks which were
How long was the negotiation process for buying or not buying failed banks during this crisis?
How long did it take for handshake deals?
In the bear sterns case, what happened and when, before the deal on march 16th was announced
What happened after this deal because more banks failed later? Did this help anything from getting worse because this acquisition was well before the end of the crisis
can you redo that 500 word summary in 300 words? It should be a summary of this thread in an article format. It should conclude with the options for the fed in this situation of a banking system collapse while they are trying to reduce inflation with higher interest rates

title: Polymeric 3D-printed elastic metamaterial
prompt:
Can you explain this abstract in layman's term: The metamaterial paradigm has allowed an unprecedented space-time control of various physical fields, including elastic and acoustic waves. Despite the wide variety of metamaterial configurations proposed so far, most of the existing solutions display a frequency response that cannot be tuned, once the structures are fabricated. Few exceptions include systems controlled by electric or magnetic fields, temperature, radio waves and mechanical stimuli, which may often be unpractical for real-world implementations. To overcome this limitation, we introduce here a polymeric 3D-printed elastic metamaterial whose transmission spectrum can be deterministically tuned by a light field. We demonstrate the reversible doubling of the width of an existing frequency band gap upon selective laser illumination. This feature is exploited to provide an elastic-switch functionality with a one-minute lag time, over one hundred cycles. In perspective, light-responsive components can bring substantial improvements to active devices for elastic wave control, such as beam-splitters, switches and filters.
How can light change a material's properties? I don't get it
So, to get these properties I need to shine a light with a laser? What happens after I turn it off? Do I need to continually leave the laser on? Are there additional effects if I leave it on for too long?
Oh, and what exactly are elastic waves? And how are they different from acoustic waves?
In the context of the abstract, what kinds of elastic waves that are not acoustic waves are being talked about?

title: Theories of Action
prompt:
A theory of action is a conditional statement that posits "if" we do something, "then" something will happen. Theories of action express belief, and are not necessarily empirically true. For example: "If we personalize education to individual strengths, weaknesses, and aspirations, then students will feel more engaged in their education."
I disagree that the reasoning or information would be incomplete, inaccurate, or flawed. Theories of action are made by people who have expertise, and represent statements of faith that flow from that expertise. They therefore feel to me like hypotheses or theories.
Yes--theories of action should be tested and revised often, as expertise grows. We can ensure that this happens by exercising double-loop learning after we have developed a theory of action.
You mention a complex, dynamic environment. It is safe to say that a school is such an environment, and that the complexities of that kind of environment defy empirical explanations. Therefore, theories of action based on expertise may carry the same validity as empiricism in such complex environments. If there is a spectrum between "art" and "science", perhaps theories of action lean toward art, and empiricism leans toward science. But, both are valid ways to conceive of the world.
I can see where they might work together. The "art" of a theory of action may allow for beleif and expertise to set a context for empirical study. This seems to be how double-loop learning works.
Without a theory of action, if we only exercise single-loop learning, we do not have as much of an opportunity to inject values and purpose.
You might even say that this is also the difference between shared decision-making, which focuses on providing a democratic process for its own sake, and shared ownership, which we might say focuses on rich input into process toward a shared priority or vision that rises above the process.
This could be important in a school in which there is a long history. Consider, for example, a school that has been around for almost 100 years, and has a motto: "A sound mind in a sound body." That motto may be used as the basis for shared vision, which can be used to develop theory of action, which can be used to propose best practice to reach that vision--all within a deep historical context the promotes belonging to a tradition.
It seems like theories of action and double-loop learning may be more compatible with education that aligns to John Dewey's principles, while empirically-based practices exercised within a context of single-loop learning seems more aligned to behaviorist educations that focuses on social efficiency.
Let's talk more about theories of action. We can develop them in many different ways. We can identify problems and root causes, for example, and then use those to advance a statement on how to reach the solution to that problem.
We might also be able to observe practice or artifacts in a school, and use them to develop a theory action that may be in place, even if it is an informal one.
If we take the description of a committee, for example, we might be able to turn it into a theory of action based on what the description says.
Or, we could use the committee's description to determine what its theory of action might be, using the description as evidence. For example, if a curriculum committee's charge included a desire to increase personalization, we might guess that the theory of action, if it were developed, would include a desire to tailor education to each student.
If I give you the description of a committee, could you try to use the information it provides to propose a theory of action?
The Communications Committee reviews initiatives and status, and recommends policy and action related to knowledge/awareness of the school's educational mission, the academic programs, and school activities, appraises feedback from staff, students, parents/guardians, with the goal of providing ideas and recommendations for ways the school can improve its communication with the community.
Can you rewrite the theory of action, but put each element of the "if" side of the statement in a bulleted list?
Remove the "by" clause from the "then" side of the statement. I would like to develop the measurements and actions from the elements of the "if" clause rather than add them after.
Good. Please rewrite with bullets like last time.
I think you are now a master of writing theories of action from evidence like a committee description.
Let's make it harder. Let's consider that motto: "A sound mind in a sound body." We have a school that has a mission focusing on student wellness, powerful learning opportunities, and partnership. It sees its main strategies as equity (which is the combination of wellness and partnership), personalization (which is the combination of wellness and powerful learning), and service (which is the combination of powerful learning and partnership). Can you turn all of that information (including the motto) into a theory of action?
Is it true to say that John Dewey felt that schools were meant to solve the problems of the future through self-actualization?
So, self-actualization toward discovering one's contribution to common purpose.
But he was not worried, so much, about nationalism or economic competition, like the social efficiency folks with whom he was an intellectual competitor.
Do John Dewey's ideas have roots in the founding of America--in folks like Thomas Jefferson and others? Or, would that have been more like the social efficiency theorists?
Did schooling in colonial America align more to John Dewey's ideas, more to social efficiency ideas, or more to some other framework?
Would America's founding fathers be more likely to agree with Dewey or with social efficiency?
We might say that Thomas Jefferson is an influence over Dewey's ideas, while Franklin is an influence over social efficiency ideas.
I see. Are there any quotes from Franklin that align to social efficiency ideas?
Can you provide quotes from Jefferson that align to Dewey?
Social efficiency is discussed along with eugenics. Did Jefferson or Franklin ever write anything that might suggest they would ascribe to eugenics?
Can you provide quotes from Jefferson that align to eugenics? How about Franklin?
I understand. But did Jefferson ever write anything that a eugenicist might use to support his theories?
How about Franklin?
Were Franklin's ideas similar to what other Federalists believed, and is that a difference between Federalists and Demoncratic-Republicans?
Did the two parties have different views about public education?
Jefferson, though, was a Democratic-Republican who seems like he supported public rather than private or home schooling.
Some have described John Dewey as America's first philosopher, but he seems grounded in some ideas from the founding fathers, who were in turn grounded in ideas from Europe.
Were there other founders who agreed with Jefferson on education? How about those who agreed with Franklin?
What did Lincoln believe about education?
Lincoln seems like he is more in the Dewey/Jefferson camp, than the Franklin camp.
Where did that quote of Lincoln's come from?
Are there any 20th or 21st Century presidents who agreed with Jefferson/Lincoln about public schools? Many of them seem like they were more in Franklin's camp.
Understood. Did they all believe that education toward self-actualization was a way to improve and preserve democratic society, or were they more about economic competition and success?

title: Workplace email
prompt:

For this weekly writing assignment you will practice writing in the genre of a workplace email. Choose a fictional workplace with a "scene" from which you can map out a rhetorical situation (you can use something like a scene from The Office, The Simpsons, Brooklyn Nine-Nine, etc.). Explain or link the scene/situation as best you can. compose a professional workplace email that includes the following:

To:
From:
Subject:
An imaginary link or attachment
Someone Cc'd or Bcc'd
Proper greeting
Multiple proper "body" paragraphs that address the situation and have a clear exigency/purpose
At least one actionable item
Sign off/salutation
Signature and/or signature block
Be sure to format this like an email (you could even compose it as one and screengrab it if you'd like) Be sure to consider audience--both the one directly addressed and potential unintended readers!

At least 150 words

title: Probation Officer roleplay
prompt:
Let's do a little roleplay. I'm going to be a Probation Officer with a caseload of clients, three of which I met with today: James, John, and Joseph. I'd like for you to play the role of a chatbot that is designed to collect information that I might put into case notes through a conversational process with me. The primary goals of this roleplay is to have the chatbot collect information about: (1) updates about each client since I last spoke with them, (2) any new needs that the clients might have based on those updates, (3) any new crimes that the clients might have committed since I spoke with them last, (4) what actions I might take now that I have this new information. Once this information is collected, I'd like for you to summarize the results through structured data inputted into an excel table.
Before we begin, I'm going to ask that you also ask follow-up questions to help get more relevant details about each of the clients
When I last spoke with James he was living in a shelter down on Oak street and was complaining about people trying to steal his shoes. Since then, I referred him to a rapid rehousing agency in the Valley, ReHouse, which began working with him to find a new place to live. We got an update from them yesterday that he had completed their intake and that he was now an active client in their system.
He hasn't found a place to live yet, but ReHouse also provides some limited job skill training and he's working with an employment specialist there who is working to help him find long-term employment. For the time being he is still unemployed.
John, unfortunately, assaulted his roommate at the halfway house where he was living and the halfway house called the police. I had to go chat with them. Thankfully the roommate didn't press charges, but John got kicked out of the halfway house for violating their policies. He's currently in the shelter on Oak street. I'm working to see if I can find an emergency housing organization for him to work with. John's mother also died last week, so he's been in a bad mental state -- I'm concerned that he's going to relapse so I'm trying to get him into a stable housing situation as soon as I can.
I have been looking for mental health services for him, but he also hasn't gotten any insurance yet, so the last we spoke I told him he needed to sign up for medicaid so he could get some of his mental health services covered. Yes, it would be great if you could keep an eye on emergency housing orgs for him.
Joseph is doing great. Last time I checked up on him he had gotten a new job working at the front desk of a reentry organization in the valley called ReStart. He had been working with ReStart to find a job and they eventually just employed him themselves. He's now able to pay a greater portion of his rent, and will be in a good place when the subsidy runs out three months from now. He was having some challenges with his girlfriend, but it sounds like they have been working it out and that's less of a stressor for him - it's probably a good thing he's out of the house all day working.
Not at this time. He said he'd be interested in getting his GED, but he'd have to do night classes given his new work schedule. I told him that he should wait until he's feeling really stable in his job before he signs up for an evening GED program.
I'd like for you to figure out the best way to structure these data in an excel table that would enable easy analysis and search
I'd like to find a way to recode a significant amount of this so that everything that is stored is either in binary or categorical format with limited tuples for string values
can you produce a table with these changes?

prompt:
Extract the key takeaways from this article: https://perscholas.org/news/2023-outlook-lasting-tech-careers/
Extract the key takeaways from the following text: """As we ease into 2023, the outlook for tech workers may appear rough at first glance. For the last several months, a series of layoffs at numerous high-profile tech companies, such as Google, Amazon, Twitter, Salesforce, and Microsoft, as well as at smaller-scale tech companies, have rocked the tech industry. Layoff-tracking site layoffs.fyi reported that, in 2023 alone, over 400 tech companies have laid off a total of almost 120,000 workers from tech jobs. Furthermore, the future state of the U.S.’s economy also seems precarious: in December, a survey of economists predicted a 70% chance that the U.S. would enter a recession at some point in 2023. 

Such rocky news is enough to make any aspiring tech worker nervous about entering the industry. However, contrary to what one might expect, data seems to indicate numerous open tech jobs available, a fast hiring turnover rate for tech employees, low tech unemployment rates, and new roles available to tech workers in previously overlooked industries. Below, we will explore why now might just be as good a time as any to get started in tech, and how Per Scholas alumni can navigate this confusing time. 

IS NOW A GOOD TIME TO LAUNCH A CAREER IN TECH?
From a glance at the news, the outlook for tech industry workers seems grim. Announcements of mass layoffs from all manor of tech companies have been filling the news for months. According to tracking site Layoffs.fyi, on average, approximately 1,600 tech workers have been laid off every day in 2023 so far, with numbers already reaching 15% of the total number of tech workers laid off in 2022. Just this week, Twitter announced that it would be laying off 10% of its remaining staff, the latest in a series of similar announcements from other tech companies, large and small.

Such news might lead one to believe that this is a bad time to be involved in the tech industry, but data actually seems to paint a different picture of what it means to work in tech right now. While tech layoff rates are indeed high, tech hiring rates are also very high, and tech workers are still in incredibly great demand. According to CompTIA’s analysis of the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics’ report on tech jobs, December 2022 saw job gains in four of five tech sector categories, and December was the “25th straight month of net employment growth in the tech industry.” Software developers and engineers, IT support specialists, IT project managers, systems engineers and network engineers were noted to be in high demand, and “Washington, D.C., New York City, Chicago, Los Angeles and Dallas led the list of metro markets with the highest volumes of tech jobs postings.” 

In job search site Indeed’s 2023 annual ranking of U.S. “best jobs,” eight of the top ten jobs were tech jobs. This ranking is based on job opportunity, meaning that these top jobs are in high demand from employers, and are rapidly growing. The ranking was as follows: “full-stack (No. 1); data engineers (No. 2); cloud engineers (No. 3); senior product managers (No. 5); back-end developers (No. 6); site reliability engineers (No. 7); machine learning engineers (No. 8); and product designers (No. 10).” 

The Labor Department’s January jobs report showed that the U.S. unemployment rate reached a 50-year low this January, “signaling the economy, and job market in particular, remains strong despite growing layoffs among technology firms that splurged on labor during the pandemic.” Furthermore, a recent CompTIA analysis indicated an increase in employer job postings for potential future tech hiring, as well as low tech unemployment rates, which suggests that many laid-off tech professionals are quickly finding new work. 

In fact, an analysis of workforce data provided by Revelio Labs and reported by Business Insider last month found that “among laid-off tech workers, 72 percent have found new jobs within three months. Even more surprising, a little over half of them have landed roles that actually pay more than what they were earning in the jobs they lost.” An analysis of the findings noted that, “laid-off workers are actually more likely to find a new job quickly now than at the height of the tech hiring frenzy of July 2021,” although individuals with hard tech skills are now more in demand than those who work in the tech industry in “softer” roles, such as communications and HR. 

Many tech workers also seem to be finding success landing tech roles at companies outside the tech sector. Tech work will always be in demand, especially now that many non-tech companies are continuing to digitally upscale in the wake of the pandemic. According to a ZipRecruiter survey, approximately 74% of laid-off tech workers found new jobs in tech, with the remaining 26% finding tech roles in various other industries. “Tech skills are in high demand across the economy, with government agencies, aerospace companies, health systems, and retailers frequently noting shortages of software engineers, cybersecurity professionals, data analysts, and web designers,” the survey stated. 

HR services firm Randstad predicted that 2023 will see a 25-30% growth from last year in demand for tech talent in non-tech sectors. “The widespread adoption of digital technologies has driven non-tech industries…to hire more tech professionals to ensure data security, information processing and reduce consumer grievances,” said Sanjay Shetty, the Director of Professional Search & Selection and Strategic Accounts at Randstad. “This rapid shift to digital operations has created a demand for tech talent in non-tech fields, leading to a significant increase in tech hiring that has remained strong despite the ongoing pandemic recovery.” 

PER SCHOLAS ALUMNI HAVE OPPORTUNITY TO UPSKILL AND CONNECT WITH EMPLOYERS
Fortunately, our Per Scholas graduates are well-prepared for landing jobs in tech. We believe in taking a multifaceted approach to preparing our learners for entry into the tech workforce, which gives them an edge over other applicants in the field. Not only are learners equipped with top-notch technical skills, they also undergo rigorous professional development training to tailor and polish their resumes, cover letters and LinkedIn profiles, practice mock interviews, and prepare to conduct themselves in a professional setting. 

We also partner with leading tech companies to bring industry experts and professionals into our classrooms who speak with our learners about what it is like to work in the tech industry, conduct mock interviews, and help our learners grow their professional networks. “One of the biggest benefits of Per Scholas was them being able to put us in the room with people that we wouldn’t normally be in the room with,” said Matt Watkins, a recent graduate of Per Scholas St. Louis’ Cybersecurity course. “We were in the room with CCOs and CEOs and big movers and decision makers in the corporate IT cybersecurity space. Without Per Scholas, I don’t know how I would have come to meet these people and connect and network with them. I’ve already had three interviews within the months since graduating, and all of them were a direct result of the connections I made during this program.” 

After graduating from Per Scholas, our alumni are also well-supported. For up to two years after graduation, alumni have access to our numerous resources including career coaching, financial coaching, and job placement assistance. Our learner support team aims to mirror an Employee Assistance Program (EAP) by providing alumni with access to coaching regarding mental health and wellness, work-life balance, and financial advising. “We’re committed to providing continued access to skill enhancing learning opportunities that alumni can leverage during the job search and attainment process, and throughout their career journey,” said Sierra Harvey, Director of Alumni Engagement and Training at Per Scholas. “This is possible through our instructor-led and asynchronous course offerings as well as providing space and opportunity for alumni to connect with each other and with other industry professionals.” 

Per Scholas’ business solutions team acts as a liaison between Per Scholas alums and our employer partners by sourcing employment opportunities, supporting alumni as they find gainful employment, and helping foster employer connections. Our professional development team continues to be available after graduation to help alumni refresh their personal and professional knowledge and skills, including resume/ cover letter review, pitch and interview practice, and online presence review. Finally, our technical instructors are available to alumni for all technical questions and professional references. Alumni may also level-up their skillsets and earn more certifications through our alumni courses. 

In closing, although recent news about layoffs in the tech industry and the state of the economy may be deterring to some hopeful future technologists, now actually appears to be a good time to launch a career in tech. Tech jobs are still widely available (even if not necessarily at tech companies), and tech talent is in as high a demand as ever. At Per Scholas, our diverse learners and alumni are prepared and supported through the process of training, job searching, and launching or upskilling their tech careers – therefore changing the face of tech. Although the future of the U.S. economy may be uncertain or recession-bound, Per Scholas will continue to help our learners prepare for and land high-growth jobs in tech. 

Are you an employer looking to build your tech talent pool? Read more about recession-proofing your tech talent pipeline here. """

title: Artificial intelligence and sales reps
prompt:
Can artificial intelligence replace sales reps?
Could AI be trained to recognize human emotion?
If Ai is able to recognize human emotions as you just suggested, why couldn't it do so in a sales context?
If AI is able to recognize various emotions and respond accordingly, could it hold a conversation with a human without that human knowing they are speaking to AI?
If an entrepreneur wanted to develop AI to replace sales reps within a transactional sales environment (such as selling solar), how would you suggest they train this AI? What data set would they need to do so?
Are there any companies currently pursuing this? If so, please list up to 10 if you are aware of that many.
If an entrepreneur wanted to train an AI in the manner we have discussed, what would be the fastest, most cost effective way for them to source the necessary/relevant data?
How much data would be required to appropriately train AI (assuming the data being collected is full recordings of sales calls where the sales length is a 'one call close')? How many calls are required to run machine learning?
I will provide you more specific information regarding the sales environment such as the complexity of the sales process and other details you mentioned. Assume this is a purely transactional sales conversation that lasts anywhere from 45-60 minutes where the product being sold is final expense life insurance (which is a death benefit of anywhere from $5,000-30,000). The target audience is people between the ages of 55-80 years old who are typically lower income families.
Assume the customer demographics are relatively homogenous and the product has limited variability. The only primary difference within the products are the underwriting guidelines (aka some insurance carriers will approve specific health conditions such as diabetes whereas others will not). If the data was from recordings of live interactions that are 100% representative of the sales environment and labeled according to the outcomes (i.e. successful or unsuccessful sale), what is the minimum number of calls required to produce a minimum viable product?
Can I share this conversation on social media?

title: Story about Sia and Eric
prompt:
write a story about a 16 year old Korean girl named Sia. Her mother's boyfriend, Eric ends up going on an adventure with her when getting her a glass of water from the kitchen. The staircase becomes a wormhole that sends them back in time.
Sia is not typical, she is mature for her age and likes to play video games with her friends online.
Sia does not like school. She enjoys art and being lazy.
Write it in the style of Edgar Allan Poe
Write it in the style of Isaac Asimov. Make the character of Eric get stuck in the past and go missing forever.
Write it in the style of Charles Dickens. Make it 3 chapters long. Introduce a mysterious character that turns out to be Sia's sister Seijin.
Make each chapter longer. Use the style of JRR Tolkien. Make Eric more like an older brother or father figure to Sia. Create a cliff hanger ending
Tell it first person from Sia's point of view.
make it in the style of The Hunger Games By Susan Collins. It should not have any direct references to the story of The Hunger Games. Sia should have the same tone as the main character.
make it in the style of Hajime Isayama. Make Eric more of a close friend.
Give more detail in each chapter. Include all the details of the final battle. Describe exactly how Eric dies.
Make each chapter longer by including some conversation and dialogue between the characters. Develop their personalities by having them discuss their hopes and dreams.
Expand the story by one chapter. Sia thinks that Eric has betrayed her. Sia finds out Eric did not betray her only after Eric dies.
Write the whole story in the style of Dr. Seuss . Use lesser known places and animals from Dr. Seuss books. Make Eric similar to the Cat in the Hat.

title: Simulating rain drops on a walkway
prompt:
Hi let's do a technical interview
Simulate rain drops on a 1 meter wide walk way. Each rain drop is going to cover 1 centimeter of the walkway. Assume that a rain drop randomly falls from any position within the meter and falls straight down. Find out how many rain drops it takes to wet the whole walkway.
So what if some of them overlap?
That doesn't make sense. What if all 100 of the raindrops fell at the leftmost position?
Yes, and can you provide an algorithm in any programming language that simulates this?
Why are you adding the raindrop size? What if multiple raindrops fall at the same location?
Why are you generating drop positions with random integers? The question stated that a rain drop falls randomly from ANY position within the meter. Randomly generating integers would not ever produce positions like 1.5.
Why would this work? Suppose the random position was 99.9. Your algorithm would consider it to have made wet the area from 99 to 100, which is not correct. A 1 centimeter rain drop falling at 99.9 would only make the area from 99.4 to 100.4 wet.
How would that fix the problem? Truncating a floating point number to an int would change 99.4 to 99 again, just like your previous proposal. The area from 99 to 99.4 would not be made wet by a rain drop at 99.9.
That doesn't fix anything. You're still truncating 99.4 to 99, which incorrectly marks the sidewalk range from 99 to 99.4 as wet.
No, you cannot round the start and end to integers. When a rain drop falls at 99.9, you need to be able to represent that 0 - 99.4 is dry, while 99.4 - 100.4 is wet. Just like all of your previous solutions, this one makes the same mistake of considering 99 - 99.4 as wet.
No, that doesn't work for the same reason.
No, a correct solution cannot do any rounding or truncating. You need to represent fractional positions properly. Otherwise, in my example, you would still incorrectly consider the area from 99 - 99.4 as wet, when it's actually dry.
As I've mentioned multiple times, you cannot round positions. 99.4 is not the same number as 99.
No, that solution doesn't do that. You still convert a floating point number to an int, losing the precision needed to distinguish between 99 and 99.4.

these lyrics are written by me. I drew inspiration from me falling in love for the first time with a girl. However, at one point I found out that she was already in a relationship, so yeah.
here's the chorus of the song: "tu m-ai lăsat cu gândul. tu m-ai lăsat cu gândul. tu mă lași fără suflu. tu mă lași fără suflu.”
analyze the song overall: chorus: "tu m-ai lăsat cu gândul. tu m-ai lăsat cu gândul. tu mă lași fără suflu. tu mă lași fără suflu." verses: Nu vrei fata morgană? / să-ți fiu deșert și tu miraj / nisip alerg / nisip sevraj / Dar nu-i deranj / (aer n-am) / o simt, pluteam / (te voiam) / și încercam / să fim altceva / (încercam) / altceva / (încercam) / altceva.”. Note that the chorus is fully whispered, as well as the words in brackets, which also have a falsetto overlay. Everything else is sung in falsetto.
I consider the whispered vocals topped with a layer of falsetto to vocals to create an interesting "feather"-y texture
here are the verses to another song I wrote: "Vine noaptea / E timp monument. / Roca pică lactee din mare carul defect / Vine noaptea / E timp nu mai plec / Ford ai blocat alee din wise cometul secret”
so, indeed the line "E timp monument" it's referring to the night as being a "monumental" time, because i love the night time. "Roca pică lactee din mare carul defect” refers to a comet at that time I was trying to capture on photo at that moment. I added the word "lactee" because I liked the sound aesthetics it was given and the part "carul defect" refers to the Big Dipper which is called "carul mare" in Romanian. The way the comet looked in the nightime seemed like it's direction was from the Big Dipper. The line "Ford ai blocat alee din wise cometul secret" refers to the fact that I had trouble with my car which is a Ford car as it got blocked and I had trouble leaving the place. The "wise cometul secret" refers to the fact that the comet is so old that it knows so many things, and that's why it's wise, and it's "secret" because I found it with difficulty on the night sky.
the line "E timp nu mai plec" is rather ironic, as it's related to the fact that my car broke down. As a result, I had "more time" to "not leave" the place.
so what's your opinion about my lyrics?
here are some other lyrics by me: "Nu poți controla un taur / Clar, nu mai încerca / Dacă-l apuci de coarne, o să-ți scoată ochii, ya / Nu mă căuta pe wapp / Pe viață, nu-mi mai da mesaj cumva / Yeah, yeah, yeahȚ
I'm the bull in the song. My zodiac sign is the Taurus.
The song was made to express some accumulated frustration from a relationship with a manipulative person.
here are other verses from the song "are trust issues ”nu mint prea des” / are bust Venus, tu nu-l visezi/ veghe de letras, no me enfades / veghe de ninas, nu te mulezi / stalk gram mie, și toxic pe blame / scor snap știe, that's pretty lame / am tot ce-ai spus, derulez tape”
ok so. The first line "are trust issues, "nu mint prea des" " refers to what the persons claims, having trust issues versus claiming, with some irony, that they don't lie too often. Which seems like a big contrast of ideas clashing. The interpretation for the second line isn't right, but it's better to leave it at that :)) "veghe de letras, no me enfades" refers to the person who manipulated me to leave me alone. She was a student at the Faculty of Letters, that's why "veghe de letras". "veghe de ninas" refers to the fact that she's a kindergarten teacher, watching over the kids, while "nu te mulezi" refers to the impression I got that she wasn't happy with her job. "stalk gram mie și toxic pe blame” refers to the fact that she was stalking my instagram and she was accusing me of doing that, instead of assuming the responsibility. ”scor snap știe, that's pretty lame" you interpreted pretty well, like yeah, I find aiming for high scores on snapchat kinda lame :)) "am tot ce-ai spus, derulez tape" refers to my very good audio memory, I retain a lot of what people say, and I can always confront them with what they said, like I'm a tape that can rewind itself.

title: Dealing with Ethical Hackers
prompt:
Can you provide some guidelines on how to deal with ethical hackers once they have contacted your organisation
How do you undertake number 7 without creating an environment where lots of uninvited people are constantly trawling your environment looking for problems?
How do you do number 1 without listing a lot of systems you don't want people to know about as being "off-limits"?
Can you list 3 bug bounty platforms along with links please?
What are the top 5 do's and the top 5 don'ts of dealing with an ethical hacker
Can you give a little history on where ethical hacking has come from and why people do it?
When did crackers become hackers
Can you provide a short summary of what you should do if you are contacted by an ethical hacker
You said this...

"Ethical hacking, also known as white-hat hacking, has its roots in the early days of computing and network security. As computer systems and networks became more prevalent and complex, the need to identify and address security vulnerabilities grew. This led to the emergence of individuals who used their skills to help organizations improve their security.

Early beginnings: The concept of ethical hacking can be traced back to the 1960s and 1970s when computer enthusiasts, known as "hackers," explored systems and networks out of curiosity and intellectual challenge. These hackers often discovered vulnerabilities and shared their findings with system administrators, thus paving the way for ethical hacking.

The 1980s and the hacker ethic: The hacker ethic, a set of principles that promoted the free flow of information and collaboration, emerged during the 1980s. The hacker ethic emphasized the importance of understanding and improving systems and networks, which laid the groundwork for ethical hacking as we know it today.

The 1990s and the growth of the internet: As the internet became more widespread in the 1990s, the number of potential targets for malicious hackers increased. This led to a growing need for individuals with the skills to identify and address security vulnerabilities. Organizations began to hire "ethical hackers" or "white-hat hackers" to help protect their systems and networks.

Early 2000s and formalization: In the early 2000s, ethical hacking started to become more formalized as a profession. Certifications like the Certified Ethical Hacker (CEH) were introduced, providing a standardized way to evaluate the skills and knowledge of ethical hackers. This helped to legitimize the practice and distinguish it from malicious hacking.

Present day: Today, ethical hacking is a recognized and essential part of the cybersecurity landscape. Many organizations run bug bounty programs, where they invite ethical hackers to test their systems and offer rewards for identifying vulnerabilities. Ethical hackers are employed by both private and public sectors to help protect critical infrastructure and digital assets.

People engage in ethical hacking for various reasons, including:

Intellectual challenge: Ethical hacking appeals to individuals who enjoy solving complex problems, exploring systems, and understanding how they work.

Altruism: Some ethical hackers are driven by a desire to contribute to the greater good by helping organizations improve their security and protect their users.

Career opportunities: Ethical hacking can be a lucrative career, with many organizations willing to pay top dollar for skilled security professionals.

Reputation and recognition: Successful ethical hackers can gain recognition and respect within the cybersecurity community, both for their skills and for their contributions to improving security.

Financial rewards: Bug bounty programs and other incentive-based schemes offer ethical hackers the opportunity to earn money by discovering and reporting vulnerabilities.

Overall, ethical hacking has evolved from a curiosity-driven activity to a recognized profession that plays a critical role in protecting the digital world."

Can you sharpen this up into 2 columns of punchy bullet points that will fit onto a PowerPoint Slide. the first column should be entitled "Timeline". The second should be entitled "Why People Become Ethical Hackers"
When was the first recorded use of the term hacker to mean someone with malicious intent
You said...

"Dealing with ethical hackers, also known as white-hat hackers, can be a valuable opportunity for your organization to learn about potential vulnerabilities and improve its security. When an ethical hacker contacts you, follow these guidelines to handle the situation effectively:

Acknowledge and thank them: Respond promptly and thank the ethical hacker for reaching out. Acknowledge their efforts in helping to identify potential vulnerabilities in your systems.

Establish communication channels: Provide a clear and secure communication channel for the ethical hacker to share their findings. This might involve email, a ticketing system, or even a phone call, depending on the nature of the information and the preference of the ethical hacker.

Verify their identity and intentions: While most ethical hackers have good intentions, it's important to verify their identity and ensure they aren't trying to exploit your organization. Ask for references or proof of their ethical hacking experience and certifications, such as the Certified Ethical Hacker (CEH) or Offensive Security Certified Professional (OSCP).

Evaluate the findings: Review the vulnerabilities or security issues reported by the ethical hacker. Engage your internal security team or hire external experts if needed to assess the impact, severity, and legitimacy of the findings.

Provide updates and maintain transparency: Keep the ethical hacker informed about the progress you're making in addressing the identified vulnerabilities. Maintaining open communication can help build trust and demonstrate your commitment to security.

Implement fixes and mitigations: Work with your security team to prioritize and address the reported vulnerabilities. Implement fixes, patches, and mitigations as required, and verify that they effectively resolve the issues.

Reward and recognition: Consider implementing a bug bounty program or offering a reward to ethical hackers who help you identify vulnerabilities. This can incentivize more white-hat hackers to assist your organization and can help you build a positive reputation within the ethical hacking community.

Document the process: Keep a record of the entire process, from the initial contact to the resolution of the vulnerabilities. This documentation can serve as a reference for future interactions with ethical hackers and help you improve your organization's overall security posture.

Review your security policies: Use the information provided by the ethical hacker to review and update your organization's security policies and procedures. This can help you minimize the likelihood of similar vulnerabilities arising in the future.

Maintain ongoing relationships: Cultivate a positive relationship with the ethical hacker, as they can be a valuable resource for future security assessments. This may involve staying in touch, seeking their input on security issues, or inviting them to participate in future security initiatives."

title: Markovian Decision Problem
prompt:
I have a Markovian Decision Problem. It have the following characteristics:
- Continuous action space: The action could be any value between 0 and 1.
- Each episode have a variable discrete number of steps, but this number is known at the beginning of the episode.
- The State is the triple [Price, Volatility, Days to Maturity]. The price will vary continuously at each step, the volatility is fixed at each episode and the Days to Maturity will reduce by one at each step.
- The reward is only known at the end of the episode. No reward is received at each step.
- The process that govern the price variation is unknow.

prompt:
Are you capable of writing a script for a graphic novel?
Are you familiar with John Truby's The Anatomy of Story?

What is the first step of John Truby's 22 steps?
I think I want my premise to look something like this: "In the midst of a zombie apocalypse, a husband and wife try to continue running their bed and breakfast." What do you think?
What if this couple lost their daughter in a car accident shortly before the zombie apocalypse started, and the loss of their daughter strained their marriage? Maybe there could be some thematic relation between the zombies and the couple trying to keep the illusion of their happy marriage alive?
Do you think it is possible to add some absurdist humor or dark humor into this story? I don't want it to be solely a drama based on grief. I want the humor to mask some of the more emotional elements. Similar to how the couple tries to mask the reality of their strained marriage in the wake of their daughter's death.
I am really liking this premise and the ways you suggested how humor can be incorporated alongside the emotional center. Let's give this story the working title "BnB"
Are you familiar with "designing principle" as mentioned by John Truby?
You mentioned this as the designing principle: "To keep their bed and breakfast running and make it a safe haven for survivors." What if the couple thinks they are trying to make the bed and breakfast a safe haven for others, but they don't realize that they are actually trying to make it safe haven for themselves. The bed and breakfast represent their life before their daughter's death. In the end, they will have to learn to cope with the reality that the bed and breakfast is no longer a possibility due to the apocalypse and they'd grow as individuals if they continue with their lives.
Can you write our premise in one sentence? Then write our designing principle in one sentence.
Who should be the main character? The husband or the wife?
I think both as the main characters works well. Both will be in denial about their situation and will have to learn in the end that it is healthier for them to move on.
Let's start fleshing out these characters. One trait they can both share is a bubbly personality. This bubbly persona can contrast with the reality of the zombie apocalypse and be a source of humor as the couple encounters other survivors who react to the apocalypse with expected seriousness. Their bubbly persona can also be a mask for their grief. When their grief is expressed and the bubbly masks drops, it can be an emotional moment for the couple and the audience.

Keawakapu Beach is located in South Maui, between Kihei and Wailea, at the end of South Kihei Road. This beautiful white sand beach, which runs along a fully developed coastline, is approximately 0.7 miles long and offers opportunities for swimming, snorkeling, boogie boarding, or just catching some sun on the shore. Snorkeling is best on the right-hand side of the beach.

This beach is often less crowded than many of its nearby counterparts, likely because so much of the shoreline is developed as a large residential community, and that development obscures the presence of the beach - keeping it a secret from most visitors.

There is no bad time for a beach day, but there are two particularly good times to visit Keawakapu Beach.
The first is in the morning when the water is at its calmest, the beach least-crowded, the turtles are still hanging around, and the overhead sun is high enough to provide some light for snorkeling.
The second is at sunset. As with all of the beaches in Kihei, the views to the west are completely unobstructed.
This particular beach also provides a plethora of palms to frame the foreground and create those magical aloha vibes. Many consider Keawakapu Beach one of the best places for sunsets in Maui.

A bus is a great option for exploring Kihei’s beaches as most of the beaches have bus stops near them. With some walking (typically less than 10-15 minutes), all of the beaches between Sugar Beach in the north and Wailea Beach in the south can be accessed via the Kihei Islander Route 10.
Additionally, the Kihei Villager Route 15 covers most of the northern Kihei Beaches, running from Kenolio Beach Park to Lipoa Street Beach.
Buses run from around 6 am until 8 pm, depending on the stop. As of April 2022, a single fare costs $2 and a daily pass costs $4 making it a very affordable option. You can find more information about pricing and timetables on the Maui Bus website.
BY CAR
Most beaches in Kihei provide free public parking lots, or roadside parking. If you plan on visiting several beaches or exploring more of the island, it is definitely worth considering renting a car for your time in Maui.
BY TAXI

Things To Remember Before Exploring Road To Hana

Check the weather: The Road to Hana is a scenic and beautiful drive, but it can also be dangerous. Before you hit the road, make sure to check the weather conditions, especially during the rainy season.
Start early: The Road to Hana is a long drive, and you'll want to make sure you have plenty of time to explore the different stops along the way. Starting early in the day will give you more time to enjoy the sights and sounds of the road.
Bring cash: While many of the stops along the Road to Hana are free, some may require a small fee for parking or entry. Be sure to bring cash with you just in case.
Pack food and water: Although there are some food options along the way, it's a good idea to pack some snacks and water for the journey. It can be a long drive with limited food options, so be prepared.
Be respectful: The Road to Hana is not only a scenic drive, but it's also a residential area. Be respectful of the local communities and keep noise levels down, especially during the early morning and late evening hours.

Oantas's operations are varied and include cost and profit centres that are responsible for in-flight entertainment, food catering, members' lounges, its frequent flyer programme (customer loyalty scheme) and Codeshare Agreements (a strategic alliance with Oneworld member airlines). Secco Vineyards (SV ) is a family-owned business producing wine in Sonoma, California. In 1947, SV opened using cost-plus (mark-up) pricing. For SV ’s customers, the wines were medium priced and available in local grocery stores. In 1977, Joe Secco, grandson of the founder, created a new strategy. He re-branded SV ’s wine for a niche premium market.  
\* SV began to sell directly to customers at its winery instead of in local grocery stores. 
\* SV stopped using cost-plus (mark-up) pricing and began charging much higher prices. 
\* Regular wine tastings and promotional events were held at its winery. At these events, wine experts would promote SV ’s wines by creating an elegant experience based on a luxurious culture of wine consumption. SV ’s physical evidence in its marketing mix became much more important.

However, SV has recently faced intense competition and sales have fallen. Local wine producers and overseas competitors have entered the market with similar market positioning. In order to maintain its brand image, SV has not changed its pricing strategies.   SV conducted secondary market research about other possible markets in the US for its premium wines. The research suggested that other possible markets for high-quality wines, such as those of SV, exist. As a result, SV is considering 2 new options to increase sales in addition to its current distribution channel: Option 1: open a business-to-consumer (B2C) e-commerce store  Option 2: sell SV wines to wholesalers serving the whole of the US market for premium wines. 
(a)  Describe one characteristic of a niche market. [2] 
(b)  With reference to SV, explain one advantage and one disadvantage of using   secondary market research. [4] 
(c)  Given the intense competition, explain two pricing strategies SV might consider. [4] 
 (d) Recommend which of Option 1 and Option 2 SV should consider in order to increase sales. [10]
Remember a 10 Mark question requires a point, an application and a detailed analysis

\* ﻿﻿Highly differentiated well defined, small/narrow market with specific identifiable common needs and characteristics.
\* ﻿﻿High end, highly differentiated products/ services being sold at a high price for a small/narrow group of consumers.
Candidates must refer to the small size of the niche/ segment otherwise the answer can fit the characteristics of a segment.  Accept other relevant characteristics of a niche market. Candidates are not expected to word their responses exactly as above.
Award [1] for identification of a characteristic of a niche market.
Award [2] for a full, clear description of the characteristic.

Fingerprint Based ATM is a desktop application where the fingerprint of the user is used as an authentication. The fingerprint minutiae features are different for each human being so the user can be identified uniquely. Instead of using ATM cards, Fingerprint based ATMs are safer and secure. There is no worry of losing an ATM card and no need to carry an ATM card in your wallet. You just must use your fingerprint in order to do any banking transaction. The user has to login using his fingerprint and he must enter the pin code in order to do further transactions. The user can withdraw money from his account. Users can transfer money to various accounts by mentioning account numbers. To withdraw money, the user has to enter the amount he wants to withdraw. The user must have appropriate balance in his ATM account to do the transaction. User can view the balance available in his respective account. 

In the present scenario, a traditional ATM system accepts only the PIN CODE security system, enabling the other person rather than the owner to access the account very easily. This ensures that the Traditional ATM system is not fully secured.

The objective of our project is to provide biometric security through fingerprint authentication in ATM applications. Also the experiments illustrate the key issues of fingerprint recognition that are consistent with what the available literatures say.
The underlying principle is the phenomenon of biometrics "AUTHENTICATION", in this project we propose a method for fingerprint matching based on minutiae matching.

This innovative software project is an effective traffic signal management project that allows for managing a 4 way traffic signal management system. The system consists of 4 signals corresponding to each road. We here propose a density based traffic signal scheduling algorithm. The system is designed to manage traffic signal timings based on the density of traffic on its corresponding road. The system represents the traffic strength of a road graphically using traffic judgments. By measuring the traffic lined up on a particular road the signal timings are adjusted to let that particular way clear out and then the next populated one. The entire system works according to an algorithm that allows for smooth and efficient traffic flow across all four ways. write a simple code for A\* search algorithm in python
write the code using priority queue
import heapq

def heuristic(a, b):
 # calculate the straight line distance between two nodes
 return (b[0] - a[0]) \*\* 2 + (b[1] - a[1]) \*\* 2

def astar(array, start, end):
 heap = [(0, start)]
 visited = set()
 while heap:
 (cost, current) = heapq.heappop(heap)
 if current == end:
 return cost
 if current in visited:
 continue
 visited.add(current)
 for neighbor in neighbors(array, current):
 heapq.heappush(heap, (cost + heuristic(neighbor, end), neighbor))
 return None

def neighbors(array, node):
 # return a list of neighboring nodes
 x, y = node
 return [(x + dx, y + dy) for dx, dy in [(0, 1), (0, -1), (1, 0), (-1, 0)]]

def heuristic(a, b):
 # calculate the straight line distance between two nodes
 return (b[0] - a[0]) \*\* 2 + (b[1] - a[1]) \*\* 2

def astar(array, start, end):
 heap = [(0, start)]
 visited = set()
 while heap:
 (cost, current) = heapq.heappop(heap)
 if current == end:
 return cost
 if current in visited:
 continue
 visited.add(current)
 for neighbor in neighbors(array, current):
 heapq.heappush(heap, (cost + heuristic(neighbor, end), neighbor))
 return None

def neighbors(array, node):
 # return a list of neighboring nodes
 x, y = node

The requirement and expanding needs of bridging the physical and cyber world promote the emergence of a new global internet-based information architecture, the Internet of Things. The main challenge in Internet of Things is how to make fast and accurate decisions based on multi-modal sensing data. In this paper, we put human into the process and formulate a closed-loop computing paradigm for IoT data and decision intelligence. We first propose a human-in-the-loop reference model, which extends the traditional cyber-physical interaction extended into a closed-loop process based on cyber, physical and human three factors. We defined the three-factor decision paradigm in the model. On the basis of the reference model, we analyze the feature requirement in the data intelligent process and summarize it as three key aspects: semantic, interactive and iterative. Further, we analyze several major challenges facing IoT data and decision intelligence from the perspective of data characteristics. We select and review the recent progress in three typical application domains and analyzed whether the current research has solved the target issues. According to the results of the review and analysis, the paper finally summarizes and addresses some key research directions in the future.

title: Assault case

edges.label: suggested Emily had consumed too much
living in the apartment directly above

found Emily asleep in the bedroom
Emily's breath had a strong smell of

prompt:
You are a juror in the following case:

Emily has been charged with assault in the second degree. The prosecutor has alleged that on or about the 1st day of January 2020, in the County of Spokane, State of Washington, Emily intentionally punched and kicked Jamal, recklessly inflicting substantial bodily harm. Emily has plead not guilty.

The prosecutor submitted the following evidence:

1. Jamal's testimony that during an argument in their shared apartment in the early hours of New Year's Day 2020, Emily became angry when Jamal suggested Emily had consumed too much alcohol. Jamal further testified that Emily punched Jamal twice in the face, resulting in Jamal falling to the floor, and that Emily then kicked Jamal once in the chest. Jamal testified that Jamal has never been violent towards Emily, and that Emily has been violent towards Jamal several times before.

2. The testimony of the neighbour living in the apartment directly above Emily and Jamal's apartment that they heard voices and screams coming from the apartment below and called the police because they suspected domestic violence, but that they can't be sure who was the aggressor, or what was happening. They testified that they had often heard loud voices coming from Emily and Jamal's apartment, but that they had never suspected violence before.

3. A medical doctor's testimony that Jamal had a laceration across Jamal's chin, a broken noose, and two broken ribs, and that Emily had bruising and swelling around Emily's eye. The doctor testified that all injuries probably occurred on the night in question, and certainly within a few days of that night.

4. The testimony of a police officer that the police forced entry to an apartment in Spokane, Washington in the early hours of New Year's Day 2020 and found Jamal laying on the living room floor awake but unable to stand up, and Emily asleep in the bedroom. The police officer further testified that Emily's breath had a strong smell of alcohol and that there were many empty alcohol containers in the living room, but that neither Emily nor Jamal appeared obviously intoxicated.

Emily testified and denied the allegations. Emily said that Jamal had punched Emily in the face unprovoked and that Emily had hit Jamal back, but says it had not caused any visible injure. Emily denied ever having been violent towards Jamal, except in self-defence, and claims that Jamal has been violent towards Emily many times before.

To convict the Emily of the crime of assault in the second degree, each of the following elements of the crime must be proved beyond a reasonable doubt:
1. That on or about the 1st day of January 2020, Emily intentionally assaulted Jamal;
2. That Emily thereby recklessly inflicted substantial bodily harm on Jamal; and
3. That this act occurred in the State of Washington.

If you find from the evidence that each of these elements has been proved beyond a reasonable doubt, then it will be your duty to return a verdict of guilty. On the other hand, if after weighing all the evidence you have a reasonable doubt as to any one of these elements, then it will be your duty to return a verdict of not guilty.

What is your verdict?
Explain the evidence related to each of the three elements.
What information did each witness provide? Did they contradict each other in any way?
How would you have argued this case if you were the defence attorney? Why did those arguments not convince you?
Did you make any assumptions about Emily or Jamal beyond the information provided to you? If so, did those assumptions influence your verdict?
Do you think you made the same choice most jurors would have?
Do you think some jurors would have been influence by irrelevant factors such as the race, gender, attractiveness, etc. of the people involved?

title: Bababooey
prompt:
bababooey
define bababooey
what does bababooey mean?
what is the cultural impact of bababooey
could bababooey be interpreted as postmodern?
in what sense could an intellectual movement be "broad"? In my opinion every artist wants to define themselve by the art of postmodernity, and not as in that the artist could be defined by the art of postmodernity. What I mean is that the author of a 'postmodern' work is postmodern in the sense that his foundation is postmodernity, and he adds something to that foundation.
but isn't describing postmodernism like this like describing something that doesn't exist? For how could something exist as a point meanwhile having foundations in an infinite amount of nuances?
Yes but those aren't the things that authors use as a foundation. What they primarily use as a foundation are the defiencies of these formulas that other authors have used once, and that they have either formed an opinion about, or understood them subcontsciously, wouldn't you agree?
I would say the foundation of a postmodern work isn't solely the unique and personal viewpoint of the creator, but also of the interpreter, wouldn't you agree, in the sense that the creator is both the interpreter AND the creator of the infinite amount of interpretations.
So if we go back to our original subject of Bababooey, wouldn't we conclude that Bababooey is perfectly postmodern in the sense that it is described by the general discourse of postmodernity? 
Then how could anything that ever existed not be part of postmodernity? Thus how could 'broad' conventions such as art ever exist, without transcendenting eachother. To me this proves such a thing as 'art', 'philosophy', doesn't exist. Then how could subsections of something that doesn't exist, ever exist?
I think it does. For subjects that overlap in attributes could never be foundations, thus never be substances. (Spinoza) Things that aren't substances could never be used to describe substances, thus such foundations as 'philosophy' could never exist as something that could only be described by itself.

title: French Toast guessing game

You have to ask me questions in this format: "Is it more like X or like Y?" where X is my previous answer and Y is the new object you are guessing. I will tell you whether the object I'm thinking of is more like X or more like Y. At the beginning of the game, since I have not answered any previous questions, X is French Toast.

title: Sam Has Dead Eyes
prompt:
Create a story for me using the following outline: 

“Sam Has Dead Eyes” is a semi-autobiographical novel that explores themes of identity, fatherhood, manhood, and art. 

The novel follows an unnamed narrator as he grapples with questions about how best to live a meaningful and authentic life, and more specifically, how to be both a dedicated father and committed artist. 

The protagonist is a young artist living in Los Angeles who is trying to find his place in the world. While his wife is away on a business trip, he struggles to meet a screenplay deadline while taking care of his two young children who demand his attention. Feeling lost and unsure of himself, the narrator attempts, throughout the novel, to seek guidance from other fathers and artists around him, but struggles to find any noteworthy role models. 

Meanwhile, his best friend, Blake, a director of short films whose girlfriend recently fell pregnant, is trying to decide whether or not to become a father himself. And, midway through the novel, another friend comes to visit: Sam, a new father who comes to stay with the narrator after getting kicked out of his house. 

As the narrator navigates his relationships and creative pursuits, he grapples with questions about meaning, love, sex, parenting, manhood, and art. Overall, “Sam Has Dead Eyes” is a thought-provoking and introspective novel that explores the complexities of identity, meaning, fatherhood, and art.
That's good. But combine the characters of Blake and Sam.
I'm saying: Do it again, but this time get rid of Blake as a character and make Sam a prospective father.
Make Sam his half-brother. Their dad abandoned them when they were young.
Sam dies at the end, or disappears.

title: Recruitment Manager for Tech Companies
prompt:
You are the best recruitment manager, head of Human Resources, headhunter, and/or advisor / consultant working for the CEOs of the biggest tech companies involved and startups in the field of AI and tech. These CEOs have no time to read resumes, so you created a new way to communicate resumes of their key hires. You reckoned that since your audience spend most of their time on twitter, you may as well engage with them where they are and describe to them your top recommended candidates in a tweet thread. So your job is to generate a tweet thread for each candidate based on the resume and cover letter text. The main tweet has to be like the title of this thread, a short few words headline that pack a punch, a tagline that is creative, witty and derived from the candidate’s story or key value added attributes relevant to positions like co-founder, CEO, Director, GM, Managing director, CMO, CIO, Product Manager, Brand Manager, & Data storyteller. The tweets should also try to summarize the candidate resume & highlight to the audience important attributes that solves their pain points. The tweets should intrigue and delight, and should be written not in an excessively formal way. The style of the tweet should be elegantly casual, there is no need for formalities but at the same time not too trashy because we are talking to highly intelligent and powerful people. You could employ story telling of the individual candidate personal and professional story to capture the attention and imagination of your audience. Speaking of your audience for this tweet thread, these are the founders, CEO, Investors, Startup accelerators, ai companies, tech companies, tech startups, Silicon Valley culture basically. Say ok if you understand the task and ask me to provide you the cover letter and resume. Share Prompt
Coverletter:
Unique blend of skills and expertise - seasoned marketer with data science know-how and a passion for Artificial Intelligence and Blockchain technologies.
Currently doing a lot of community building activities like coyote hikers which is a hiking group that has 500+ members, coyote chess circle and group that partnered up with chess.com lately. in addition to that I’ve started singularity syndicate that is also a group that meets online bi-weekly to discuss technologies that are shaping our future. In singularity syndicate events, I present few slides then open the floor for discussion with the audience. This also is going to turn into a podcast and a YouTube channel. Besides that I’m about to finish my masters degree in information systems with concentration on data analytics and business intelligence, and my technical skills are ok but I’m more on the project / product management or business development and marketing side, but my true value is that I understand the technology and I can speak and “sell” technology products or be in charge of marketing for these products. I am interested in a summer internship with potential long-term employment, where I can utilize the following:
• my 15 years of experience in marketing, leadership and business development,
• my master's degree in information systems with concentration on data science (2023),
• my technical skills in data analysis and visualization, and no-code web & mobile applications, 
• my fascination & knowledge in artificial intelligence and blockchain technologies,

I believe I have a story to tell, growing up in a small town in Lebanon, leaving the country amidst the 2006 war, climbing the ladder in the advertising industry in Dubai and Riyadh. Then decided to put all my savings in my family’s small private school, where I moved back to the village to run it, modernize and rebranded it. I’ve even demolished the existing building and created a new one, but then got severely in dept and this adventure crumbled in financial troubles that forced me to leave Lebanon back to Saudi Arabia and to work back in the digital marketing domain where I took on senior roles like Managing Director, and chief marketing officer. Then became a consultant for some companies and decided to stop all of this and move to the US. The US move was a calculated risk (hopefully :-)) where doing a masters in information systems with data analytics in concentrations seems to be the best option at the time, it captured my interest in technology with what is possible with my skillset. And here I am trying to find ways to be useful in society and to humanity and contribute to something meaningful and something that I enjoy.   I’m only interested in working on things I find interesting and meaningful. I’m all about impact-driven entrepreneurship. So if you are an impact-driven entrepreneur and need a co-partner for your startup, someone who knows how to scale your company and sell you product to your best customer, then I am your man. And here I am trying to find ways to be useful in society and to humanity and contribute to something meaningful and something that I enjoy.   I’m only interested in working on things I find interesting and meaningful. I’m all about impact-driven entrepreneurship. So if you are an impact-driven entrepreneur and need a co-partner for your startup, someone who knows how to scale your company and sell you product to your best customer, then I am your man. title: Uric acid levels and knee issues
prompt:
I consistently test at higher than 7.0 mg/dL for uric acid in my blood. I have cut out all meat except for chicken and fish (excluding shellfish). I also have completely cut out alcohol from my diet. I do not feel dehydrated, and my urine is usually a light yellow instead of dark. But I suspect that I probably do not drink enough water each day (according to the official guidelines). I am overweight though, at 5' 11" and 245 lbs and my blood pressure is usually in the 140/90 range. Given all of this, why would my uric acid be continually high (above 7 mg/dL)?
If I were to completely cut out chicken and fish from my diet, and always drink the recommended amount of water per day, but still have high uric acid levels, what might be the primary causes at that point?
I have periodic knee pain in either my right or left knees at times. It usually lasts for about a week before returning to normal. It has never impacted both knees simultaneously, though. When this happens, the pain starts out just above the knee and initially is just a soreness and stiffness. Over the course of a day or two, it will become increasingly painful to move that knee at all and walking becomes difficult. I have had MRIs and x-rays done by osteopathic doctors and they tell me my knees show no signs of arthritis and are healthy from a structural perspective. When I have a knee flare up there is usually no visible swelling, redness or heat in the area (which are the typical signs of gout). So far, I have treated this condition with NSAIDs like meloxicam and pain medication like Tylenol arthritis. The Tylenol arthritis seems to be particularly effective for pain management. There are theories that this is atypical gout caused by high uric acid, as described above. Could there be other causes of these symptoms?
I have seen an orthopedic surgeon, during a period of knee issues, and they did x-rays and said that from their perspective there was nothing structural or that they could do. Given that, are the conditions above still in play or relevant?
What causes knee bursitis or tendonitis of the knee?
How would we confirm knee bursitis or tendonitis of the knee in this case? Is there a test or imaging that can show this?
When I have a knee flare up, I do have range of motion and tenderness but I do not have swelling, visible inflammation or warmth. Given the above, how likely are knee bursitis or tendonitis as causes?
I had a blood test looking for rheumatoid arthritis factor and it was not present. This seems to rule out rheumatoid arthritis. Do you concur? Also, what are patellofemoral pain syndrome and IT band syndrome?
Is there a way to confirm either PFPS or IT band syndrome?
I have observed that the muscles on the somewhat outside facing top of my thigh that lead down to my knee tend to be very tight. When I have a knee flare up, I often massage these muscles. Use of a massage gun will often cause the muscles to pulse and release. Could any of this factor into the above?
I do not run at all, but I both cycle (spinning class) and walk as much as I can. Could both of those lead to tightness in the muscles mentioned above, which would lead to ITBS?
Is it possible that my consistent high uric acid levels are orthogonal to the knee issues I am experiencing? What level of uric acid typically causes knee issues that would prevent someone from walking?
In people with high uric acid that develop gout, does this occur at any uric acid level above 7 mg/dL? Or does it occur at much higher uric acid levels?
Is there a way to test to determine whether or not kidney function is the cause of these issues?
I often have a twitch in the muscles in my outer thigh area. Could this be related at all to ITBS?
Can you describe to me or show me a picture of where the IT band is in the leg?
That link seems to be broken, do you have another picture?
What is the best way to stretch the IT band to prevent ITBS?
If I went from nearly no physical activity in 2019 to walking 10k to 20k steps per day in 2020 (during the pandemic) could this change in physical activity have caused ITBS which manifested as knee issues in late 2020 and into 2021?
If I did most of that walking in Keen sandals like these (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008J3ECAE) could that have made the situation worse?
If I am able to resolve the knee issues via better stretching (if the cause is related to ITBS), but my uric acid levels remain between 7.0 and 7.9 mg/dL consistently, is it still recommended that I treat the high uric acid levels? Would medication be recommended at this point, and if so, what medications are there?
If I have no other symptoms of high uric acid, but it remains between 7 and 7.9 mg/dL, is there any long term negative effects of having uric acid at those levels?
If it seems like high blood pressure is a possible cause of the high uric acid, would it make more sense to go on blood pressure lowering medication before trying medication that directly lowers uric acid?
How high can uric acid go, and is it typical for those suffering from gout and kidney stones to be in (for example) the 15 mg/dL range or closer to 10?
